moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Nf6: The Icelandic gambit. Inferior, but against a well prepared player.
moves.5. b3: Correct, but not enough to stop black.
moves.5... Bb4: Avoidin d4. Of course, h6 is a refutation,
moves.9... h6: Unsure about how to proceed, I stopped Ng5.
moves.10. h3: Probably unsure about d4, white returned the tempo.
moves.10... g5: If I castled queenside, is in order to press on white's kingside.
moves.11. Qc2: I feared Bb2, since my black diag is weak, but after Rh-g8, there is less danger.
moves.11... Qd7: This is a good move, since threats Bf5. White can stop it, but...
moves.12. Nh2: white chooses to retreat, and probably thinking about Ng4, exchanging some pieces and stopping the pressure. A great mistake.
moves.12... Nd4: The bishop on e2 is half-threatened after BxNc3.
moves.13. Qd3: Mistake, much better was Qd1, and accept to exchange the bishop.
moves.15. Qg3: Bd6 does the trick, but I was already looking for...
moves.15... Bxc3: And white has to defend Ne2+ forking K and Q.
moves.16... Bxg4 17. dxc3: I have two pieces threatened, but...
moves.17... Ne2+ 18. Kh1 Bxh3: The final shot. I can easily sac this bishop, since gxh3, Qc6+. If f3 (forced to defend the king), Ng3+ forking the rook. White, sensibly, resigned.
